channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: H.I.V. Infections Among Young Chinese Rising
item.description: Youths, including school and college students, are contracting H.I.V. through sex in rising numbers in China, where 70,000 new infections overall were reported in the first nine months of this year, the government said.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Chinese college students show off their World AIDS Day "Red Ribbon" health packs, which included packets of condoms, in Liaocheng, Shandong province.

item.title: Jihadist Groups Gain in Turmoil Across Middle East
item.description: American intelligence and counterterrorism officials are concerned that militants aligned with Al Qaeda could establish a base in Syria capable of threatening Israel and Europe.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT F. WORTH and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: An Islamist fighter roamed through Aleppo, Syria, last December. Infighting among jihadist groups has recently mitigated their threat there, but that may not last.

item.title: Kerry and Allies Step Up Pressure for Afghan Pact
item.description: The need for a bilateral security agreement was a major issue as foreign ministers from NATO nations gathered in Brussels for two days of meetings.
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Biden Asked to Raise Case of Jailed Nobel Laureate and Wife
item.description: On the eve of the vice president’s visit, human rights groups urged him to press Chinese leaders on the plight of two of the country’s most prominent dissidents, Liu Xiaobo, and his wife, Liu Xia.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: $12 Billion Is Pledged to Fight AIDS, TB and Malaria
item.description: The amount pledged by donor countries over three years to a global fund was more than the amount raised in 2010, but far short of the goal.
item.category: Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: The Lede: Let Slip the Drones of Peace
item.description: The United Nations proudly announced the deployment of its first peacekeeping drone on Tuesday, in the Congolese city of Goma.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Secrets Inside Us
item.description: The human body is less well understood than we think.
item.dc:creator: By BILL HAYES

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Central African Republic: Attack Kills 12 Civilians
item.description: At least 12 people were killed and 30 wounded, including children, in an attack northwest of the capital, the United Nations mission there said Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Ban Sought on Political Party
item.description: Germany’s 16 states submitted a petition to the Constitutional Court on Tuesday to ban the far-right National Democratic Party on the grounds that its ideology resembles that of the Nazis.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Hopi Tribe Sues Auction House
item.description: The Native American Hopi tribe took a Parisian auction house to court Tuesday to try to block the sale of 32 sacred tribal masks.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: French Aid Group Accuses Security Forces of 2006 Massacre
item.description: The group Action Against Hunger accused Sri Lankan security forces of executing 17 of its employees during the country’s civil war, and said the government had protected the killers.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: United States: Contractor Jailed in Cuba Appeals to Obama to Press for Release
item.description: A United States government contractor jailed for four years in Cuba appealed to President Obama on Tuesday to take any steps necessary to secure his release.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel Sends Humanitarian Aid to Syria
item.description: Israel acknowledged that it was providing humanitarian aid to victims of the civil war inside Syria, saying it has funneled food and other emergency supplies.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Uncle of Kim Seen as Purged In North Korea
item.description: South Korea’s intelligence service reported that Jang Song-thaek, considered to be No. 2 in the Pyongyang government and a mentor to Kim Jong-un, has lost his positions of influence.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN and DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: The North Korean leader Kim Jong-un with his uncle, Jang Song-thaek, last year.

item.title: In Kiev City Hall, Energized Protesters Settle In for a Long Winter’s Uprising
item.description: Protesters have taken over the first two floors of City Hall in the Ukrainian capital and are taking unusual measures to assure they will not be removed easily.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters pushing for the removal of President Viktor Yanukovich of Ukraine have transformed the City Hall building in Kiev into a kitchen and hotel.

item.title: Tests on Arafat Find No Proof of Radiation Poisoning
item.description: French investigators’ conclusion partly contradicted and partly confirmed those of Swiss scientists who found abnormal polonium-210 levels in the remains of the late Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE

item.title: The Lede: Activists Fear Egypt’s Police Force, First Target of Protests, Is Out for Revenge
item.description: Under threat, activists in Egypt fear the interior minister wants to turn the clock back to 2010, when the police had total control of the streets.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Greenpeace Activists Detail Russia’s Capricious Justice System
item.description: The crew of a Greenpeace ship seized by Russian authorities in the Arctic in September described a prosecution bound by the letter of the law but remarkably opaque.
item.category: International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Crew members on a Greenpeace ship that Russia seized in September, from left, Ana Paula Alminhana Maciel, Gizem Akhan, Faiza Oulahsen, Sini Saarela, Alexandra Harris and Camila Speziale. They remain in St. Petersburg, facing charges of hooliganism.

item.title: Editor Describes Pressure After Leaks by Snowden
item.description: Testimony to Parliament from the top editor of The Guardian illustrated the aggressive investigative and cyberspying tactics increasingly faced by news organizations.
item.dc:creator: By RAVI SOMAIYA
item.media:description: Alan Rusbridger, editor of The Guardian, during the Commons Home Affairs Committee hearing in London on Tuesday.

item.title: The Lede: Video of Police Brutality in Kiev Fuels Rage
item.description: Protesters and local journalists in Kiev documented a tumultuous weekend in the Ukrainian capital in online video.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Kurds’ Oil Deals With Turkey Raise Fears of Fissures in Iraq
item.description: Iraqi Kurds are selling oil and natural gas directly to Turkey, upsetting Baghdad and Washington, which fear a broader independence for Kurds in Iraq’s north.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO and CLIFFORD KRAUSS
item.media:credit: Ayman Oghanna for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Kurdish shepherd passing a flare from an oil well in Kirkuk, Iraq. Tens of millions of Kurds live in Iraq, Syria, Turkey and Iran.

item.title: Bolshoi Dancer Gets Six Years in Acid Attack on Director
item.description: A Moscow court sentenced Pavel V. Dmitrichenko, a former Bolshoi Theater soloist, to six years in a penal colony after a trial that exposed toxic rivalries at the theater.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH
item.media:description: Pavel Dmitrichenko in a defendant's cage at court on Tuesday.

item.title: Economic Scene: Americanized Labor Policy Is Spreading in Europe
item.description: Desperate to restore competitiveness, European nations are dismantling workplace protections that once supported labor and helped minimize income inequality.
item.dc:creator: By EDUARDO PORTER
item.media:description: A protest in Portugal. Income across much of Europe has widened, but it is still quite modest when compared to the vast gap in the United States.

item.title: A Less-Equal Court, in the Name of Stability
item.description: The nations that adhere to the International Criminal Court have agreed to special rules for national leaders, but human rights groups warned that a category of privileged defendant had been created.
item.dc:creator: By MARLISE SIMONS
item.media:description: President Uhuru Kenyatta of Kenya at an African Union summit meeting in October, where he called the International Criminal Court ‘‘the toy of declining imperial powers.’’

item.title: Letter From Africa: Casting a Critical Eye on Justice
item.description: Invoking old demons of racism and imperialism, the African Union claims that the International Criminal Court is unfairly targeting African leaders.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
